content: The Act may be cited as the "Travel America Now Act of 2001". Prior to September 11, 2001, over 19 million Americans were employed in travel and travel-related jobs, with an annual payroll of $171.5 billion. The travel and tourism industry in the United States grew to be the third largest industry in terms of retail sales, with expenditures exceeding $582 billion in 2000. This industry also generated over $99.6 billion in tax revenues and created a $14 billion trade surplus for the United States. In 2000, the travel and tourism industry created a $14 billion trade surplus for the United States. Efforts are being made to ensure safe travel post-9/11 attacks and support the industry. Increased consumer spending on travel and tourism is crucial for the United States economy to recover. Encouraging the public to travel for personal and business reasons will help support working people and stimulate economic growth. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section, SEC. 25C, which introduces a Personal Travel Credit. The new section SEC. 25C of the Internal Revenue Code allows individuals a credit for qualified personal travel expenses incurred before January 1, 2002, not exceeding $500 ($1,000 for joint returns). The term 'qualified personal travel expenses' refers to reasonable expenses for travel and lodging during a qualifying personal trip within the United States. It excludes expenses for meals, entertainment, amusement, or recreation. The term 'trip' refers to travel within the United States that is at least 100 miles away from the taxpayer's residence, involves an overnight stay at a commercial lodging facility, and is taken after the enactment of this section. Personal travel expenses do not include expenses in connection with such travel. The term 'commercial lodging facility' includes hotels, motels, resorts, rooming houses, or campgrounds. No credit is allowed under this section to individuals eligible for a deduction under section 151 by another taxpayer in the same calendar year. No credit is allowed unless expenses are substantiated by adequate records. No double benefit is allowed for expenses eligible for a deduction under section 151. The amendment includes a provision for a net operating loss carryback for the travel and tourism industry, allowing losses to be carried back to preceding taxable years. The provision allows for net operating losses in the travel and tourism industry to be carried back to preceding taxable years. The term 'travel or tourism loss' is defined as the net operating loss attributable to travel or tourism businesses. The term 'travel or tourism business' includes activities related to commercial transportation, lodging, airport operations, travel agency services, and convention facilities. The term 'travel or tourism business' encompasses services such as travel agency operations, convention facilities, and other specified services as determined by the Secretary. Losses in this sector are treated similarly to specified liability losses for tax purposes, and taxpayers can elect a 5-year carryback from any loss year under certain conditions. Additionally, regulations allow a taxpayer with a travel or tourism loss to credit it against taxable income earned during the 5-year carryback period by any member of a controlled group of corporations. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending before, on, or after the date of the enactment of this Act.
